greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of partitions of n having k perfect cube parts (0<=k<=n).
comment: Sum of entries in row n = A000041(n) = number of partitions of n.
Sum_{k=0..n}k*T(n,k) = A264392(n) = total number of perfect cube parts in all partitions of n.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..200, flattened
example: T(7,1) = 4 because we have [6,1],[4,2,1],[3,3,1], and [2,2,2,1] (the partitions of 7 that have 1 perfect cube part).
maple: h := proc (i) options operator, arrow: i^3 end proc: g := product((1-x^h(i))/((1-x^i)*(1-t*x^h(i))), i = 1 .. 80): gser := simplify(series(g, x = 0, 30)): for n from 0 to 18 do P[n] := sort(coeff(gser, x, n)) end do: for n from 0 to 18 do seq(coeff(P[n], t, j), j = 0 .. n) end do; # yields sequence in triangular form
b:= proc(n, i) option remember; expand(`if`(n=0, 1,
T:= n-> (p-> seq(coeff(p, x, i), i=0..n))(b(n$2)):
mathematica: Table[T[n, k], {n, 0, 18}, {k, 0, n}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 14 2020 *)
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Nov 13 2015
